instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7050: What is D7050? Diodes between SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL and ground, these data lines allow the battery to communicate with the battery charging chip and the SMC..
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message:
Unfortunately no history, customer bought the laptop cheap thinking he could just swap out the battery.

If I unplug the power it tells me the battery is low and it will sleep soon. Coconut doesn't see the battery at all.

Considering it technically can run off the battery, I'm looking at the data lines.


<DIODE>D7050</DIODE>::1 = 3v08 - 3v3
<DIODE>D7050</DIODE>::2 = 2.189

<RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> = ok.
<RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> = ok.
<RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR> = ok.

<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> = ::1 2v2
<CAPACITOR>C7060</CAPACITOR> = ::1 2v2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: Bad ISL or SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: How can I test for this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: You can't. Start with the ISL and pray, but count on a dead SMC too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: Orange light and no fan spin with the new ISL. :/

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: Well then you screwed it up. Check soldering and or replace again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: Inspect your soldering job, it was working before replacement so....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message:
I redid the soldering and all looks okay.

There is no draw now though. The adapter is only giving 0.5v.

All fuses look okay. I haven't seen this before, any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: Soldering can be fine, but the chip is dead. Redo the whole thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: Do you know if an ISL from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> will work on that <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: yes, as long as it says ISL6259AHRTZ on it. and agreed with duke & aprendiz that this must be fucked up soldering or something else knoccked off as it was working before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message:
Thanks, I'll swap it shortly.

Soldering the first time round a bit rough, but the second time was pretty solid. ISL came off a donor board though so I'll try one I know worked before looking further.
Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message:
Swapped it out again, soldering is definitely ok this time (no really, I swear).

What does it mean when there is only 0.470v on <SIGNAL>PP18V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> is reading 61k and should be 1k...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> is supposed to be 68K, so 61K in circuit is 99% probably fine.

Looks like adapter is shutting down or not turning on. Do you have a fake adapter to test with?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message:
You're right.
I must have had the wrong PDF open. :/

I don't have a fake charger here unfortunately.


/taps fingers on desk.
I'll have to try make a plan somehow...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: Check for shorts on the DCIN bus and PPBUS. Also get a fake charger for testing, they are sometimes handy.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message:
Dead Short. As in 0.000. :/

How do I work out where the short is?
Guessing I remove a component in the middle somewhere and see which side still has the short then repeat?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message:
In Diode mode on <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>;

::1 = 0.000v
::2 = 0.004v

So would this mean the short is on the pin 1 side?
(trying to make sure I'm doing this right)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> is on the PPBUS not DCIN. But I guess PPBUS is shorted now. Measure in Ohms the resistance to GND on PPBUS

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message:
0 ohms on Pin 1
10 ohms on Pin 2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Doesn't sense battery.
threads.message: Short can be anywhere on the bus, inject voltage and see what current does. Start low cause the short is pretty low Ohm so should draw lots of amps quick. I expect something in the ISL area to heat up as that was messed with.
